description:
Delicious. The tofu tibs were actually great (I say "actually" because AFAIK tofu is not a traditional Ethiopian dish, and is easy to screw up... the tofu tasted nearly like chicken). The veggie platter was bomb. 

The food was very well-spiced - very flavorful but none of the flavors were overly intense.

Decor is on the level of a fast casual place, like slightly nicer than a Chipotle but at the level of say, Tender Greens. 

Went here for dinner on a Sunday night and there were plenty of seats.
author: Sameer J.

description:
Came here with co-workers for a quick lunch. This was my first time having Ethiopian food, so I don't have much to compare against.

This place is fast-casual, which I'm not the biggest fan of as it usually means that you pay a bit more for mediocre food. I'm the type of person who would either pay more for very high quality food or pay less for big portions and have quality suffer a bit, so fast-casual is kind of a no-man's land for me, but your mileage may vary.

As for the food itself, it was pretty tasty. I got a meat sampler and all the flavors were pretty strong and I liked the injera (fermented flatbread) they provide as a side. I just wish that there was a bit more food for what I paid is all.
author: Harry X.

description:
Price: 5 stars -- it's a value play.
Flavors: 4 stars -- very tasty.

Came in for a casual dinner. The entire place has a warehouse-meets-diner kind of vibe going on. We had the eggplant tibs plate, which was fantastic. The injera was excellent. I'm a huge fan of the sourdough-like sponge. Not sure if it's how you're "supposed" to eat it, but I love ripping it up and making little "injera-tacos"... I'd imagine this to be a great (but messy?) place to take kids for dinner :)
author: Calvin C.

description:
Tried Ethiopian food for the first time here. I took a safe option of Vegetarian Combo Platter. I am now a fan of Ethiopian food. The food seemed healthy too - not oily, protein rich!!
Injeera is like Indian Dosa and a few lentil curries are similar to Indian daal. 
Highly recommend this place.
author: Sakshi S.

description:
This was our time eating Ethiopian food and it did not disappoint! We had no idea what to order, so left it to Yelp photos. Ended up getting the combo meat and combo veggie platter.. Along with the telba (flaxseed and honey smoothie). The meats and veggies were super flavorful, and the injera (wraps) were light and fluffy. I wasn't a fan of the smoothie, but my husband finished it, per usual. 

I'm sure we'll be back since this is right in the neighborhood!
author: Kim I.

description:
This was the first time I've ever had Ethiopian, and afterwards I wasn't really quite sure if I enjoyed it or not. It was definitely very interesting, I've never had injera before and didn't know what I was supposed to expect except that my sister told me everything is "family style" and you "eat with your hands" and "there are lots of tasty meats and sauteed vegetables". I suppose those are all true statements, and it was a nice meal altogether. 

I had Ethiopian a few more times after Tadu (all at different restaurants, not back at Tadu) and I would say that Tadu wasn't the best I've had but I would definitely recommend if you've never tried Ethiopian before and want a taste of what that's like.
author: Jeanette S.

description:
Love this place! The food, the atmosphere, the drinks - just everything! 
Injera here is amazing! 

Why I was here // Came here for Saturday lunch with my bf. Not overly busy but it was such a pleasant dining experience! 

Atmosphere // clean, love the interior design and colors! 

Service // super friendly and quick! 

Food // we got our food family style 
-Kitfo Wrap // 9.50 // The ground beef was delicious, rich, and buttery. Very juicy and not dry at all! Went perfectly well with the injera wrap. 

-Meat Combo // 16.50 // Great combination of the various meats! and it comes wth injera, it's super delicious 

-Telba // 3.00 // flaxseed smoothie with honey - I really enjoyed this! Perfectly sweet and still felt like it was "healthy" 

Overall // Really love this place and I live nearby so I can almost guarantee that I will be back again soon!
author: Emily T.

description:
going to a baseball game at at&t park? Tadu is great stop on your way. I really hope this location stays around for a while because they're so damn unique.  I'm also appreciative of restaurants who state which items are vegetarian & vegan right on the menu. The knowledgable staff here help further fine tune what you might order if you are the enlightened type who trys to avoid consuming animal products. 

They are awarded stars here as such: 

1. Ambiance: It's loud but comfortable and they there's wonderful Ethiopian decorations. there are no wait staff. you order at the front and they bring it to you. 
2. Food: the stews are all very flavorful. Their spicy hot powder, available by request, is just what you'd need to bring the heat up a notch
3. Tadu is Vegetarian & Vegan friendly. They know their ingredients so they can advise which dishes will suit those with self imposed dietary restrictions. 
4. they take apple pay and other digital currency. i tried to pay with bitcoin but their PoS stystems don't accept this yet. 

I can give Tadu five stars because even though i usually reserve it for restaurants who offer vegan proteins (e.g. TVP, Gardein, Beyond Meat etc.). However, had 'Yelp!' offered reviewers a choice of several celestial bodies, I would have awarded Tadu four stars and one crab nebula! 

WHAT TO ORDER?: Get the vegetable medley  (with eggplant  or mushroom)  and Vegetarian combo‼. The injera bread is made with teff & millet (i think) so that's always cruelty free.

go Tadu!  thanks for expanding!!
author: Athonia C.

description:
What a charming, clean and delicious spot to grab Ethiopian eats. Tadu has a modern cafe feel with counter service. We dropped in for lunch and the menu had much to offer - apps, full entrees, lunch combos. 

My colleague/friend and I split the vegetarian combo platter, and it was filling for us to share (granted, we are both smallish gals). And we added on gluten free injera. Yes, gluten free injera! (If you don't have a gluten allergy, stick with the traditional injera - so freakin' spongey and perrrfect.)
author: Farrah A.

description:
It was just OK. It was my first time eating Ethiopian food and based on all the reviews, I was sold! Upon entering the restaurant, I had no idea what anything was. The woman at the counter was not helpful. From the pictures I saw on yelp, I decided to order the vegetarian combo. 

After ordering my food, I scanned the premises and all the tables were still dirty. It must have been from the lunch rush. I ask the women at the front if they could kindly clean one for me. 

I get my plate of food with a basket of rolled crepe like bread. Luckily I've watched enough travel channel to know how to eat it. 

The food overall was good but I was not blown away. Like some have mentioned, it is pretty pricey! I did leave with leftovers for dinner though. 

Would I come back? Yeah, probably
author: Marie N.

description:
I love Ethiopian cuisine but it can be really pricey where I live in Honolulu because there's only one place that serves it. So I couldn't pass up the chance to enjoy it during a work lunch in beautiful Mission Bay. This is Tadu's second location and it looks virtually brand new on the ground floor of a gorgeous new condo.

There are so many menu options to choose from, but I went for the vegetarian combo ($15.90) which I shared with my co-worker. The girl at the counter told me it was only enough food for one person, but with the injera it was perfect for us to share. The variety of flavors were great and it was filling yet light enough so I didn't go into a total food coma afterwards. We payed a little extra for gluten-free injera, which we were reassured tasted just like regular injera. FYI it wasn't bad but no where near as spongy and light as regular injera, bring on the gluten next time! As a bonus they've got gigantic bottles of Fanta soda which make the guilty pleasure of soda even more enjoyable! 

Oh Tadu, if only I could ship you to Honolulu...
author: Emi H.

description:
I thought this place was tasty enough, but a bit expensive for a pay at the counter and seat yourself sort of spot.

I got the lamb tibs with lentils and had a taste of meat platter. This came along with a side of injera for the table (sour spongy rolls). The injera was a great vehicle to soak up all the various juices on the plate.  Although my friend and I ordered two separate dishes, they came together on a large plate, separated by an aisle of salad.

The lamb was in good portion, tender enough (although more tender is always welcome), with a good lamb taste without being overwhelming. I liked how they let the lamb flavor shine through without dousing it in any sort of sauce. It left a little bit of heat in your mouth after eating it, but was not on the tongue sort of spicy. The meat was all meat (instead of some fat / sinew plus meat)-- I really would have wanted more chewy, but this is a personal preference. The lentil side was all mashed up, with good flavor from the spices. 

They weren't really doing rounds to fill up water, and the water was located behind the counter-- perhaps a filling station might be helpful! A bit short of 3.5/5 for me given the price and lack of service. The interior was cute and modern.

--
Edit: just did a quick scroll through of reviews and it looks like a number of their 5 stars are review are fake given lack of user profile photos. That's disappointing.
author: Nicole H.

description:
I have had my fair share of lunches with co-workers in SF and my recent experience with Tadu was one of my favorites by far. First of all it's easy to order food and get in and get out of there. Second of all the food is pretty great.  I opted for the vegetarian combination because I like a little of a lot of things and it did not disappoint. The Misir Wot was my favorite from the bunch. 

Bonus you can order online for no waiting. Extra, extra bonus - they have Orange Fanta to drink.

The prices seemed reasonable to me. The location was clean. The workers were friendly. The injera was perfectly light and spongy. 10/10 would recommend.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
A cool restaurant for some delicious Ethiopian food. It is a bit expensive, though.

I liked the beef tibs the best. It came with a side of injera, too.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
This was my first time having Ethiopian food! While I can't personally speak to how Tadu compares to other Ethiopian food, I've heard from plenty friends who are experienced with it that Tadu some of the best around here.

The menu can be kind of overwhelming if you've never had it before (it certainly was for me). But I'd say the best way to pick a dish here is to get one of the specialties and pick a kind of meat that you like (or veggies if you're vegetarian) and don't worry about the rest of the dish.

I have to admit, I was really skeptical of the whole scooping up food with bread instead of using a fork thing, I was sold on it by the end. The injera is squishy and spongy--it's the perfect vehicle for absorbing the delicious sauces and such that go inside. The dishes themselves are huge and satisfying. We got the kitfo wrap and the gomen besiga, and it came with various lamb cubes in sauce, a salad, and collard greens. I'd say generally the food was hearty, sour, and savory in the best ways. You'll leave super full and with leftovers even if you only get one dish! I would definitely try to come here with a lot of people to get a lot of different dishes and share them family style.

They have plenty of unique drinks too. The Ethiopian hot tea is spicy and delicious, but refreshing. We also tried the telba, which is a flaxseed smoothie with honey. It was hearty but refreshing. I can't wait to come back!
author: Claire C.

description: Very Nice section of food--environment noise could be an easy fix--will be back again--fed family of 3 just right
author: Martin G.

description:
Had a very good meal at Tadu.  I took a nice walk across the bridge from ATT park to eat here based on the great reviews. It was around 1.30 in the afternoon, so not too busy. I liked the setup... high ceilings and modern.

I got the special kitfo, rare, mild with extra cheese. It comes a side of salad and injira bread. Really good meal, the beef was not oily like it is in most other Ethiopian restaurants. Super nice ladies, they were very friendly and helpful.
author: Sunil R.

description:
We had...
Azifa Salad 
Sambussa
Veggie Combo platter
Meat Combo platter

The red lentils in the veggie Combo (Misir Wot) were the star of the show for me. I would definitely order that for myself if I came back. 

Friendly and attentive service, quick food, and frequent water refills. 

Prices are a bit steep (our total was ~$70), but the food is good.
author: Nic Z.

description:
Awesome spot for Ethiopian ! Went for dinner on a Friday afternoon and there weren't too many people as in there was no real wait. The staff was really nice, friendly, and patient and our food came out pretty quickly. 

We got the vegetarian platter as well as a meat platter. In the vegetarian platter we got some collard like greens, peas / lentils, and a potato / beets / carrot stew. For the meat we got a beef and I think a lamb stew. Overall everything we tasted was amazing, full of flavor, and just on point.

I will definitely be back and recommend anyone in the area to try this spot out and if you're by in the area, to make a trip out for this place!
author: Valeria S.

description:
First time have Ethiopian food, it's a little hard for me to understand the menu. I think some photo alone with menu would be helpful but it's probably fine because I like all the thing I ordered.

My personal favorite is the soft, fluffy, sourdough made injera. I can't have enough of them in the meal.
author: Wenjing Y.

description:
Heard great things about this place so wanted to try it. You order up front and then seat yourself down at any table and they bring the food to you. I came here before the lunch rush and still waited almost 1 hour for my food. Everyone else at my table received their food within 5-10 minutes but my dish didn't come another 40 minutes later! Waitress kept saying they were still making my dish but most likely gave my dish to the wrong table and forgot about my dish. They also did not give my table water till halfway through the meal and never refilled it after.

The food itself wasn't too bad, but portions were small for the price I was paying for and I'm just not a fan of the bread (injera). The injera was extremely sour. It was only edible when smothered in the sauces of the meat and sides on my plate. I got the chicken tibs plate. There was way more onion than chicken but the flavor of all the spices were good. Got the kik alicha wot as my side. The taste was decent but the texture of it made me feel like I was eating baby food. My friend got the meat combination and for $16, that plate is so tiny and not filling.

Overall terrible service, small portions, and overpriced!
author: Kelly H.

description:
There's so much built-up suspension around coming to this Tadu location. The restaurant in the Tenderloin is one of my favorite places to eat in San Francisco, so I was stoked when they opened up this Mission Bay location. My roommates had already gone several times, and I just never made time until now.

My friend watched our puppies while I went in and ordered for the both of us. I got the usual lamb tibs as I always do. The cashier recommended the misir wat (lentils) as our side dish, so we went with that. It took about 15 minutes for our to-do order to be prepared. Lunchtime isn't very busy. We got our food and headed back home.

I love that they gave us SO much injera, more than enough for the amount of food we had. The lamb tibs were flavorful and fresh. The chili powder was also a nice kick, and the cashier warned me about trying a little before dumping on more. 

Unfortunately I think I was too ambitious on my stomach because I gave myself food poisoning that night. My friend was fine, so I'm guessing it was my stomach's reaction to the chili powder. Because I'm so loyal to Tadu, I'm giving them the benefit of the doubt and would come back to this location again. After all, it's so conveniently located!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
I'm glad to see the House of Tadu make the intra-city trip from the Tenderloin to Mission Bay to serve their particular culinary creations. I enjoyed the hearty and flavor-filled Ethiopian dishes at the still thriving original location a lot, but the walk over there did not provide me with as much pleasure since it's way deep in the 'Loin (review: http://bit.ly/2J1bhMl). Granted, Mission Bay is a lot more sterile and youth-oriented as a neighborhood with a lot of ongoing construction. Yet, taking a leisurely stroll through Mission Creek Park to get here is a lot better for my urban-sensitive nerves than the walk up war-torn Leavenworth, and the interior here is far more modern and spacious to draw me in more than once.

The menu is just as robust here as it is in the 'Loin, and I've ordered the same dish on both my visits, the $15.90 Vegetarian Combo Platter, which offers the best of their homestyle cooking over a hidden flat of spongey injera (photo: http://bit.ly/2GkMt4h). It was quite a presentation dominated by five distinct specialties, all tasty and made with similar ingredients: Kik Alicha Wot (chickpeas cooked in turmeric, onion, garlic, and jalapeños); Gomen (fresh collard greens sautéed with onion, garlic, and jalapeños); Alicha Tiki Gomen (fresh cabbage, potatoes, and carrots cooked with a turmeric sauce of onion, garlic, and ginger); and Key Sir Wot (fresh beets and potatoes cooked with onion, tomatoes, garlic, and jalapeños).

The surprise fifth addition was Misir Wot, which is a spicy split lentil sauce made with berbere, onions, garlic, and ginger. There were hearty sooonfuls of Eggplant Wot and Buticha which is the Ethiopian version of hummus. A small salad called Azifa completes the dish. As you probably know, you're supposed to eat all of it with your hands by tearing pieces of the injera and scooping it up, something that requires more dexterity than I possess. They leave a basket of rolled injera which I noticed they freely replenished at other tables (photo: http://bit.ly/2GpKiIB). Since Jamie W. and I were watching our carb intake, we cheated and used our forks simply because injera easily becomes an unbridled addiction if we aren't careful. Yep, this has become my favorite Ethiopian meal in town.

FOOD - 5 stars...the veggie combo is a satisfying homestyle treat...if your home is in Addis Ababa
AMBIANCE - 4.5 stars...really like the clean new digs
SERVICE - 4 stars...efficient and fairly quick
TOTAL - 5 stars...if you haven't tried Ethiopian, this is the place to dip your fingers...literally
author: Ed U.

description:
I love this Mission Bay location so much better than the tenderloin one for all the obvious reasons.  It's walking distance from my home.  It's clean.  No one is peeing outside the front door.  And the food is the same!  

Stop at the counter.  Order your grub.  My faves?  The lamb tibs, special kitfo (medium rare for me), and gomen with a bunch of injera.  They offer gluten free injera if that's what you prefer.  I haven't veered away from these 3 items yet because they're just so stinkin good.  

Ethiopian food is one of my faves and tadu is definitely one of my preferred spots outside of other places in Oakland.  

So far, I haven't had a line to battle and tables are plentiful.  Make sure you grab an ethiopian beer to complete your meal.  5 stars.
author: Jen W.

description:
Have you ever seen a coworker bring in some incredibly delicious food and you're like, "Hot damn, can I have some of that??"

Well ever since our company moved to China Basin, I've frequently spotted colleagues of mine order takeout from Tadu Ethiopian Kitchen. Although I've personally never had Ethiopian food before, I can't help but salivate when I see stuff from this restaurant. 

And so when my friend and I were looking for a quick lunch spot to catch up at, I immediately suggested we check out Tadu Ethiopian Kitchen.

According to their website (http://taduethiopiankitchen.com/menu-house/), Ethiopian food apparently encompasses a blend of veggies and meat - all surrounded by flavorful spices, sauces, and bread. One look at their menu and even I, a noob at this sort of cuisine, could tell that this was definitely the case here. At Tadu, pretty much every item - be it side, plate, or salad - included a large variety of scrumptious-sounding ingredients. The dishes that caught my eye the most were the Tibs Plates, which were essentially a mix of protein, a veggie side, and some bread. 

In terms of pricing, this place is a bit costly for lunch. Sides themselves are a shade under $10, whereas entrees go from ~$10-$16. I guess for San Francisco standards it's not bad, but don't expect to pay under $10 here.

I ended up getting the Beef Tibs with Kik Alicha Wot  (chickpeas). Here's what I thought of my experience:

-- DAMN GOOD FOOD!!! --
So thankful that I popped my Ethiopian food cherry here because the Beef Tibs was 10/10 amazing! 
First off, I thought the cubes of beef tasted great. Each piece was quite flavorful and juicy as well. Secondly, the sauce was perfect - probably all thanks to that berbere spice. Furthermore, I'm glad I ordered the chickpeas because it offered a nice, soft texture to juxtapose with the chewiness of the beef. And if it couldn't get any better, this dish also came with a sprinkle of fresh lettuce, some tomatoes, onions, and jalapeños.  

Perhaps one of the best parts, though, was the injera bread. Omg this Ethiopian-style flatbread threw me off guard. It was sponge-like, extremely soft, and tasted like heaven!

-- QUIET, SPACIOUS SETTING --
Despite the fact that we came in around lunchtime, Tadu was quite empty. We were able to settle in to some nice seats right away. The restaurant was fairly big, it looked very clean, and all I could here was ... silence! Not a bad place to have a meeting or a catch-up. 

-- PRETTY DECENT SERVICE --
Overall, the employees here were hella nice and considerate. For instance, they brought out glasses of water without us even having to ask! And, they were extremely efficient as well! This is definitely a great spot if you want a fast and decent lunch.

Beyond the food, ambiance, and service, one additional perk about Tadu was the location. This restaurant is only a few blocks down from both the MUNI and the Caltrain, so getting here should be a cinch! Plus, it's also like right next to AT&T Park, which is AMAZING because sometimes you might want something more than just stadium food. And since the cuisine options at Mission Bay are really lacking to say the least, this might be your best option for delicious food. 

All in all, for those of y'all who are craving Ethiopian food in the city or perhaps you just want to try it for the first time, Tadu Ethiopian Kitchen is the bee's knees. But who knows, I have no idea what constitutes amazing Ethiopian dining. However, what I do know for sure is that this place ain't bad! I give Tadu a "Nice-su, you can take your parents here and they'll be happy" rating. Yidesetu!

Eat well and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
This is my first time trying ethiopain dishes. its quiet different. i got the beef platter, which comes with a side dish (greens, beets, lentil, etc.), side of salad, and some shells to wrap the meet in.

the shell is a different texture and flavor in it self. Its like a purple color, and it has air bubbles that makes it light. but its a bit sticky. with the beef, onion and beets mixed it was pretty good. But, I think I prefer nan bread, which i know i am comparing two different types of dishes and culture. But, its my preference. And im comparing it to chinese dishes as well, their portion is small.

They beef was a little tough for me, and they had the chunk of whole pepper and the time. not what i will like to chew on when i am eating finger foods
author: Bonnie C.

description: My best experience at an Ethiopian Restaurant. I used to live in West Philly (Philadelphia) where there many Ethiopian kitchens and restaurants. None was like I want to go back too. The main issue was always 'presentation'. This restaurant is serving very familiar types of dishes but well presented. Although I should say the Chicken Wot was super tasty. It made me curious about the ingredients and the owner patiently explained to me different types of spices and even brought me a sample of a dish I was curious about. I even went ahead and studied the spices and food names at home. Would want to go back, but not with my toddler. Pretty much everything was super spicy for him.
author: Mehrnoush S.

description:
Delicious...! 

I always order the vegetarian combo because I like the variety: 
Gomen: Collard Greens
Misir Wot: Lentils
Kik Alicha Wot: Chickpeas
Alicha Tikil Gomen: Cabbage and Potatoes
Key Sir Wot: Beets and Potatoes
Azifa and Buticha: kind of like lentil paste and chickpea paste I just eat along with the salad. 

NOTE: Their injera has has flour in it. You can ask for gluten free injera (which is the traditional way to make it), but it will cost you extra. 

Yes, the food is a bit in the pricey side, but location and cleanliness make up for it.
author: Sheewon B.

description:
Great Ethiopian spot in the heart of Mission Bay. I get very excited whenever there is a new place opens near by work, so I have been passing this place for weeks and finally decided to crash it for lunch. 

First of all, this was my first time ever trying Ethiopian food, and I LOVED it. I had no idea that there were so many veggie options and so many flavors! I haven't had lunch this good in Mission Bay in a while!!! 
I got ALICHA TIKIL GOMEN, it is a veggie plate with fresh cabbage, potatoes & carrots cooked with turmeric sauce of onions, garlic and ginger. I absolutely loved the vegetables and bread which was very unique and tasted absolutely delicious.

The people are so friendly, and you can sense that the restaurant is family business. I find it extra special when a restaurant ran by family and they invite you to be part of their community through love of food.
I am very excited to find my new favorite spot in the Mission Bay!
author: Galya T.

description:
Love this place!

Love the veggies and the assorted meat options. As my wife is vegetarian we get a veggie sampler and then something with tofu. I have yet to have something I didn't like there. 

Service is friendly.
author: Benjamin T.

description:
Given there are no other Ethiopian restaurants nearby (and frankly not a lot of any kind of restaurants nearby), +1 Star for this location of Tadu, but otherwise it's a 3 Star experience for me. 

The vegetarian combo was flavorful and the injera fresh and noticeably sour as it should be. The food can hold its own with other Ethiopian spots. 

The vibe of the interior is a little too modern and sterile for me. It felt like it should be part of a chain. I much prefer an experience with Ethiopian wicker and artwork and warmer lighting. 

Portions are surprisingly smaller and prices are higher than every other Ethiopian restaurant I've been to in SF, Oakland, and the South Bay. Those two factors probably work out to half the expected value. Rent is high, I get it, but sheesh. 

If you're craving Ethiopian (I've totally been there), don't want to venture out of Mission Bay, and don't mind paying what's essentially a convenience fee,  cool, this is a good option. But don't let it be your only experience of Ethiopian dining.
author: Cristina S.

description:
I am often skeptical of Ethiopian restaurants in the city--they never quite hit the spot when it comes to the flavors I crave, but Tadu did not disappoint! I headed into their newest location to see for myself what my friends had been raving about.

I love the space that Tadu is in-- large windows, lots of natural light, bright colors and Ethiopian decor.  And unlike many other Ethiopian restaurants, the food came out really quickly which is a huge plus. We wanted to taste as much as possible so we ordered 4 different dishes--Kitfo (a seasoned raw beef traditional dish), Lamb tibs (cubed lamb sautéed with onions and spices), Beef firfir (beef meat in a spicy tomato based sauce mixed with pieces of injera), and a veggie combo which included multiple veggie dishes including lentils, greens, and cabbage. All the food was seasoned and cooked to perfection and it really fulfilled my cravings. I walked away completely satisfied and happy. 

Added bonus, the owners (a wife + hubby duo) are a total pleasure and the service was great! I'll be coming back for sure!
author: Ruhama G.

description: Enjoyed the food a lot. Didn't realized same place as in tenderloin until yelping. Friendly staff and manager came by to check on us after Food arrived. Would highly recommend
author: Allen G.

description:
Every time my family and I enter this restaurant we are greeted with a warm welcome and big smile. 

Food is amazing if you enjoy Ethiopian Food. 

This is my go to place to eat when I am in the area.
author: Jeffrey B.

description:
The husband was craving Ethiopian, so he found the nearest highly rated Ethiopian place on Yelp. I believe this is the second location for Tadu; the original location is very highly rated with 4.5 stars and over 450+ reviews. 

We came here on Sunday for a late lunch. Parking was incredibly easy. We found a spot located right in front. The restaurant wasn't what I was expecting. It's like a quick counter service type of spot with elevated SF prices. 

We placed our order at the counter for a combination meat platter and a combo veggie platter served family style (about $16 each). The menu also had Injera wraps and salads, so I think it's more aimed as a quick lunch spot rather than a traditional sit down restaurant. It's a very casual place.

The food was served fairly quickly; we were the only ones there since it was like 3:30 pm. The portions seemed on the small size, but we did ask for more injera, which was given complimentarily (we didn't know before we ordered, but other reviewers here also mention that).  

The dishes themselves were really nice and this really hit the spot! However, I think I prefer a more traditional Ethiopian restaurant with big family style platters and more ambiance. For the price, I'd expect bigger portions or a nicer ambiance and atmosphere.
author: Rebecca G.

description:
I decided to try this place out because I have never had Ethiopian food before. 

I ordered the Alicha Tikil Gomen ($11.50) while my friend ordered the Lamb Alicha Banatu ($14.50). 

When we first received our food, I noticed both of our dishes were combined onto one plate. This is really bad for people who are vegetarian. If you are vegetarian, you should ask the employees to put your food onto a separate plate. 

The Alicha Tikil Gomen tasted good. It kind of reminded me of a very mild Thai yellow curry. I liked how the carrots, potatoes, and cabbage pieces were very soft. 

The sauces on the lettuce were strange to me. One sauce had the texture of tuna from a can and the other reminded me of hummus. They were both sour. 

Our dishes came with tons of injera (on the side and at the bottom of the curry)! I thought the injera was going to be sweet since it reminded me of the rolls that have creme on the inside. Instead, the injera tasted sour and reminded me of sourdough bread. The texture was soft and it was cold. The injera contrasted with the Alicha Tikil Gomen and sometimes overpowered this dish. At one point, I got sick of eating the injera because there was just too much!

My friend did not like the Lamb Alicha Banatu because there was not enough meat. 25% of that dish consisted of injera. 

I will probably try other places before coming back. This place was a bit pricey.
author: Kristina M.

description:
Can I give minus stars? We were a group of 5. We ordered 2 sambusas, 1 beer, 2 tibs and 1 vegetarian combo. $77 including a generous tip. The tibs include salad and a side. What do we get? Everything in a plate with chicken and tofu mixed in (half of us were vegetarians). There was no extra misir wat which we ordered as sides for tibs. No salad. We asked them to give our food separately. 

Guess what we get? Small portion of chicken tib, no sides, no salad. Tofu tibs, no misir wat. The veggie platter was a joke. Barely any portion and half a plate!!! We paid for the fucking food. 

We ask the server why we got such less portions- she said she will call the manager. The manager never showed up. We asked again, they told us she's "busy". After 15 minutes, while our food is getting cold, we are told that the manager will call us to handle our problem.What the hell! We just left after that. 

We waited for this place to open for so long because we live right across and we were so excited! So not worth it. Horrible service and no regard for their customers. I've never seen such blatant disregard for ones clients. Never going back.
author: Namrata J.

description:
This place is a winner!  Love the fast casual vibe: pay at the counter, get a number and someone brings you your food pretty quickly.  Great addition to the neighborhood, which is only beginning to develop its culinary roots.  And the food is just delicious!  Love that you can get individual portions that sport a variety of dishes and are just the right amount of filling.  I liked the food at their Tenderloin location, but the ambiance is so much better here.

Lamb Tibs: A big portion and very tasty.  Large chunks of lamb cubes that are seared on the outside and a little rare inside.  Really like that the onions were nice and browned, which paired very well.  The pepper pieces were a bit large in comparison, but had nice smoky grill marks

Misir Wot: I love berbere!  It just doesn't feel like a trip an Ethiopian restaurant without a berbere heavy dish.  These lentils were just that.  My technique was to get a good smear of the misir wot on my injera and then scoop up a large lamb chunk and some onions.  All the flavors and textures together were amazing.

Injera: Spongy.  Filling.  As expected.
author: Adam B.

description: First time eating at an Ethiopian restaurant . Super delicious, friendly staff, clean and warm a atmosphere. 12 years old daughter felt in love after eating a chicken dish.
author: ckt p.

description:
This is a new restaurant in mission bay. It has a very trendy, modern, clean feel to it. First, you order at the counter, pay, grab your number stick, and pick a table to sit. The staff brings water, a basket of injera, and food out to your table soon after!

The cashier recommended I try the tibs plates, and I got chicken tibs with a side of lentil. Everything tasted fresh and flavorful!! I loved the veggies that came with my chicken. The lentil was slightly spicy. The injera was spongey, moist, and soft. Also, they will refill your injera basket free of charge. The portions are large as well--be prepared for a food coma!

The service here was top notch. The staff were extremely helpful and friendly!

Although I didn't order breakfast, they do serve breakfast until 2:30pm, and those dishes are very affordable! ($5.50 to $11.50)- I'll be back to try it some other time.
author: Hailey K.

description:
The veggie plate was good. The dressing on the salad was epic.

I need all of the veggie plates to fully rise to the epic goodness of the salad dressing. In the meantime, Imma keep ordering take-out. Because it's good.
author: Gabriela W.

description: Sadly I was disappointed by this place. I ordered the beef and mushroom tibs and was expecting greatness based on my friend's recommendation. Unfortunately, all I got was overcooked beef, tiny dollops of the side dishes, and a disappointing couple of leaves of butter lettuce posing as salad underneath. The only part of my meal I found acceptable was the injera. Save yourself from disappointment and go somewhere else!
author: Camille B.

description: Nice, casual dining, great service, and tasty (and healthful) eats!  I don't eat meat, so appreciated their many veg. options.  Also, although I did not partake, they have a broad selection of beers and wines.  I will definitely be going back for more.
author: Deborah H.

description:
My bestie was visiting from SoCal and on a dreary day, we didn't want to venture far. Thank goodness we're getting more of a diverse restaurant scene in the area!

Ambiance: Very clean, casual, and modern. 

Service: Friendly staff. The guy at the counter taking our orders lent us suggestions when we were being indecisive. There's even a lady walking around offering up Ethiopian coffee free of charge (which by the way is delicious!)

Food: I ordered the chicken tibs with misir wot (spicy lentils). My friend ordered the lamb ribs with misir wot. While mine was pretty good, I think my friend's dish was better. It's served with a salad atop injera -- this light, soft bread you use to pick up everything.

Drinks: I just had some water, but the little cup of Ethiopian coffee we were offered was amazing. They give you cream and sugar if you request it.

Cost: For the area, it's not too bad, but it's a tad on the pricey side. The convenience, friendly service, and quality of the food make it worth it, though.

Would I return: Yup! It's a solid go-to when looking for a place nearby.
author: Leana L.

description: One of my favorite Utopian restaurants.  Not sure if because of the food or their amazing customer service, probably both....
author: Camille B.

description: Delicious meal with friendly helpful and generous staff. Trust the waitresses recommendations because she won't guide you wrong. It's quick, savory, fresh, and tasty
author: Kaison T.

description: Their veggie combo plate is absolutely delicious. Also, workers confirmed with us that everything in the veggie combo plate... including the dressing on the salad is vegan! Was extremely happy to hear that and will definitely be coming again.
author: Reese E.

description: Clean place with kind service but there's better Ethiopian food in the city. I didn't like the eggplant and nothing else really stood out as stellar
author: Jason X.

description:
I ordered the beef tibs and kik alicha (chickpea stew), which came with a basket of with injera (sourdough flatbread) and salad. The beef tibs were served in a sauce cooked with crispy sweet onion and garnished with fresh sprigs of rosemary. The kicker was the Berbere, or Ethiopian chili powder, which added an earthy, intense flavor and together with halves of jalapeno really spiced up the dish. Whenever the heat got too much for me I just patched up with some chickpea stew, which was creamy but light and instantly cut out the heat with its mild, savory sweetness. 

My only qualm with the dish was that the beef was somewhat dry and tough, which might not be helped at this price point because a) they're using less expensive and therefore tougher cuts of meat and b) beef tibs are sautéed by design, not slow cooked for tenderizing.

The food was delicious, the server was kind and attentive, and the space clean and modern. Will be back again!
author: Rujia Z.

description:
For what you pay: Great.  Just right.  Looking for a full belly? Come here!
Ambiance: One of the cleanest Ethiopian joints I've ever been in
Service: nice.  Slow when busy but worth the wait.  Effort is processing
Taste: WOOOOAHHHH.  This is good Ethiopian food!!

Looking for above average? Uninterested in sub par Ethiopian?  Looking for a mouthful of cultural experience and mind blowing flavor? Look no further.  Tadu had u at above average. Tadu is a small multi location Ethiopian joint that packs a punch with flavor.  Wife and I are Ethiopian/Eritrean enthusiasts and go to Oasis, Sheba and New Eritrea on the reg.  The flavor here at Tadu is unparalleled. If I could have lunch every day here, I would. However, when it comes to dinner spots, it depends what your looking for.  If your looking for the best Ethiopian food Id say here but if your looking for a romantic date then maybe start with Sheba.  While Tadu is super Tasty it's modest Mission Bay sparkle packs tables along a window display that allow passerbyers to glean over your food while you eat.  Some people are bothered by this. Doesn't bother me though, I keep stuffing my face with fluffy injera and spicy berber.  Which leads me to believe they are not gleaning over my food as much as disgusted by my misdemeanor of etiquette.  Well, the satisfaction on my besmeared face should be convincing enough that the food is worth disregarding delicacies 

Oh yeah, and they have TOFU TIBS!! NO other Ethiopian place does this! I repeat NO OTHER. This limits vegans and vegetarians. This was by far my favorite thing about Tadu.  Those tibs were great! The miser wot was also amazing. 

Will definitely be back.
author: Rob C.

description:
A solid Mission Bay outpost of a popular Ethiopian restaurant in the Tenderloin. Portions might be a tad smaller and prices a tad higher than you might be used to elsewhere here in the West Bay and over in Oakland where there are a lot of great Ethiopian places, but the dishes are still more than big enough to tide you over, if not provide leftovers.

As for the beef tibs, they were nicely done and came with a choice of side, which for me was a slightly bitter (in a flavorful way) kik alicha. It came with a decently sized basket of injera, which I could have had more of if I wanted. 

Service was very courteous and obliging, and they even give you utensils here. This might not be as authentic as using your hands 100% of the time, but I appreciated having the option of alternating between my hands and a fork and knife.

Overall, a great addition to a neighborhood that could sure use more diverse places like this.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Awesome Ethiopian hole-in-the-wall restaurant.

I highly recommend the veggie combo. The meat dishes are also very good, but I really like their Yemisir Wat.Take friends and order family style so you can try the most yummy dishes possible.
author: Peter K.

description:
Come on the weekend for Ethiopian Coffee brewed and served from a Jebena(traditional pot)! 

The new Tadu location serves the same great food, as the Tenderloin spot, in an tasteful environment fitting the Mission Bay neighborhood. Ethiopian paintings and fabrics decorate the walls. The dinning area is the size of a coffee shop but the high ceilings and industrial lights make the restaurant feel spacious. 

I've come here a couple times to try the veggie combo, meat combo(pictured below) and special kitfo. Every time the staff have been attentive and friendly. My favorite dishes here are the lamb ones: Gomen Besiga and Yebug Alicha. Both a flavorful, tender and spiced authentically.

The only disappointing dish was the Special Kitfo. The flavor and presentation doesn't measure up to the top tier restaurants found in LA, DC and Addis Abeba.
author: Daniel W.

description:
T'was a familial decorum and t'was an pic delight for the Ngasty Womyn dynasty. Order and sit style with superbly prompt and efficient service. Start with the sumbusa's. If you haven't tried Ethiopian food before I would suggest the meat combo and or veggie combo, which is a sampler of all the major items, pair with their Meta Ethiopian beer. We ate family style with three people and it was plenty.

Interior Design: Great open spacious design, calming sea color palette, comfortable chairs, and authentic art collection.
author: Ellina Y.

description:
Cheap, shareable Ethiopian food. Clean, fast, attentive service. 

The only thing that confuses me is the difference between all the items on the menu and they do a really poor job of explaining both on the menu and in person.
author: Aria S.

description: This place is such a gem. We just moved to the neighbourhood and have been here for less than two weeks and its already out second visit! Highly.recommend!!
author: Pavan D.

description:
I ordered the chicken tibs plate with misir wot. The chicken was slightly tough, probably, it wasn't cooked through. It had a lot of onion.The favor was good but tasted more like fajitas. Also, the chicken lacked seasoning. The injera rolls we're good too. I wish it was a bit more sour. The Misir Wot was tasty. The food was overall a 3.5/5.
       The service was quick & friendly. It's a good neighbourhood eating joint.
author: Ananya P.

description: Excellent - suggest the chicken tibs.  Great - friendly service and nice little place - will come back.
author: Mike S.

description: Came back for lunch - the food is pretty tasty, particularly the injera bread (they gave a large portion of the injera, as well).  But . . . it took about 40 minutes to receive our food.  When it arrived, there was no apology or explanation, and we had to rush to eat it so we could get back to work.  Can't imagine going back again -- the food is fine, but overpriced for what you get and certainly not worth the wait.
author: Ed K.

description:
Tadu is a Ethiopian restaurant in Mission Bay. It's what you would expect with an Ethiopian place (injera with meat+vege+sauce). The food is very tasty. Unfortunately, the prices are 3-4$ above what similar SF, but it's in line with what you would see in Mission Bay. The portions are also a bit short of what you would expect. Finally the dishes were very oily comparatively. I will definitely be coming back to see if they get their ducks in a row, they are new so they probably don't have their shit completely together.

Service is nice but a bit slow. The place is very clean and pleasant to be in.

I ordered the:
Chicken tibs - a bit small for 12$
Vege platter - a bit small for 15$
author: Sean W.

description: The food is 4 stars, service 1-2 stars. Come on, get it together please.  Why do we have to ask for everything server supposed to do?  Please bring napkins, bread, plates...
author: Viktoriya Z.

description: The best restaurant I've ever had they have the best spices they cater to Us non meat eaters I love this place My New favorite Ethiopian restaurant the food was excellent
author: Yusmine B.

description:
The food is delicious. Lots of flavor, great variety in the veggie combo.  Definitely as good as the best Ethiopian restaurants I've had in the Bay Area. 
I highly recommend veggie combo, mushroom Tibs and Lamb Tibs.. 

Always happy to come back.
author: Gize A.

description:
(Disclaimer: slightly delayed review)

I probably spent a good six months refreshing their website and staring wistfully into the empty shopfront but it's finally here - my favorite restaurant in SF, in my neighborhood! My wallet and waistline are a little less pleased, but what can ya do?

My husband and I are creatures of habit, so we typically order at least the kitfo (either special or regular, but always rare - that's nonnegotiable - with an extra sprinkle of mitmita) and their veggie combo or their mushroom tibs, but you can't go wrong with any of their entrees. The menu here also has a few specialty items not offered at the TL location; the bozena shiro and gomen besiga are my personal favorites. Another benefit of this location: so much more room. I think we've had to wait for a table maybe once?

Overall, the prices are a little higher (understandable, given the location), but the service is just as warm and the food is just as fragrant, delicious, and comforting. We're probably here at least once a month since we're temporarily living outside the city but once I'm back, you'll probably have to wheel me out of here on a weekly basis.
author: Elaine L.

description:
3.5 stars.

I've been looking forward to trying this place out since the first "coming soon" signs started appearing on the windows.

I came around 12pm on a weekday and as expected, they were very busy! I ordered the Tofu Tibs $11.50) with a side of lentils to go. The total came out to be a little over $12. They gave me a number and I waited about 15 minutes for my order to come out. Although the wait was a bit longer than hoped for, the staff were very nice, attentive and apologetic. 

The tofu tibs was pretty good but, I would've liked more of the tofu tibs. It came with a side bag of two long injera rolls (which, since it was my first time trying something like it, was surprisingly sour and spongy) but the tofu tibs was also on top of a layer of injera. So I felt the bulk of the dish was mostIy injera. It would be better if instead of the bottom layer of injera, there would be more vegetables. The side of lentils was delicious. It was on the saltier size, but it pairs nicely with the injera.

Overall, good food, though a bit pricey, but a nice change from the typic asian fusion or mexican food popular in the area.
author: Jennifer C.

description: This was my first time having Ethiopian and to be honest, I didn't really know what to do expect but holy cow I was so pleasantly surprised with Tadu! Portions are big and super flavorful, even if you're not a typical veggie eater, you'd love this place! Would highly recommend the Chicken Tibs & Veggie combo plates. Prices are a little up there but I guess that's to be expected with the Mission Bay & SF neighborhoods.
author: Pam N.

description:
It finally opened and it was totally worth the wait!

Tadu is a great little spot with a huge Ethiopian menu. I got the Kitfo Sandwich and the meat and cheese was incredibly flavorful with a spicy kick on very big and fluffy bread. The food was great and I can't wait to come back and try so many more things on the menu!!
author: Jeffrey S.

description: We had a family plate with injera, veg combo, chicken and lamb tibs plates. You must try this with your friends. Its awesome! Staff is very helpful in suggesting dishes based on your preference. Definitely worth going!
author: Bhuvan M.

description:
Shared the Veggie Combo and Meat Combo among 4 people and we were all stuffed. It was nice to sample the different meats and veggies with the complementary injera bread. I think I liked the collard greens, the reddish beets like vegetables, the lamb, and chicken the best. 

Overall Tadu had a very nice and clean atmosphere and offered a very  pleasant dining experience.
author: Kate X.

description:
This is my neighborhood favorite. My bf and I get the vegetarian combo (always) and a meat dish to share. Lamb tibs and special kitfo are good meat dishes to try. The telba drink is really yummy too. 

Love coming here regularly as the week come to an end. Enjoy!
author: Yoon K.

description: I'm a fan of Ethiopian food. Tasty, fast and healthy. Tadu checks all the boxes. We had the  chicken tibs and the vegetarian platter. Everything was so good we ate it all. Recommend Tadu for a casual dinner.
author: Jeffrey O.

description:
The food was very good. Had the vegetarian sampler and everything was tasty. 

Served on plates with utensils but can still eat with your hands.
author: Habibi S.

description: Me and my sister in law came here. We were talking and I mentioned it was her birthday, and they gave us Samosa on the House!!!!! Two vegetarian and two meat samosas. That was very generous and sweet of them. Thank you. The restaurant is really clean and nice. Great location. Service is great and the food was really good too. The injera was very fluffy and light. I will definitely come back. Thank you so much
author: Amal K.

description:
This place is delicious!  We go just about weekly and the food is getting better and better!  (if that's possible).  I've been to the Tenderloin restaurant but spend a lot more time near mission bay so was pleased to stumble onto this venue one hungry night.

They are so friendly and professional.

The injera is plentiful and I always have the vegetarian combo!  My partner has tried almost all the tibs and he recommends them.  The tea is also super tasty.

I'd love to try the breakfast one day!
author: Elsa T.

description:
I'm sorry but this food is terrible. I've tried it multiple times since it's in my neighborhood and I want to like it, but I cannot find anything even remotely edible on the menu. 

The bread is sour/tart. The vegetarian dishes are extremely bland and tasteless. I think this place is mostly driven by hype over exotic cuisine. I would have given 1 star but the service is good.
author: J. K.

description: Food is really good! Injera was on point and the service was quick. I got the veggie platter and everything was super good, next time I'll ask for it spicier. Will definitely be back!
author: Brandon R.

description: Wonderful experience, great food, quality service, and very fresh ingredients.   I highly recommend going.
author: Carlos M.

description:
I'm really hoping this place does well in Mission Bay as the immediate neighborhood is in dire need of more restaurants. I've always been a fan of Ethiopian food but don't eat it often as Ethiopian restaurants are not very common. 

My friend and I ordered two of the vegetarian 'entrees' that were served on the same plate. People are saying this place is expensive but you get a TON of food and it's very fresh / non-oily. I found the value for the money to be fine - not cheap but not expensive either. Ethiopian is a bit of an acquired taste but I liked the food quite a lot. Food took a while to come to our table but I assume that's because everything is made to order.

Great place for vegetarians, vegans, or people with allergies. They don't seem to use nuts, sesame, dairy, or a lot of those usual culprits often. 

Overall, I don't think I'd seek out this restaurant specifically but definitely stop by if you are a local.
author: Sarah S.

description: Meh.  This places checks all the boxes but not in any exemplary fashion.  All the staple dishes are there but they are all a bit mediocre.  Their beef with mushrooms tibs dish was disappointing; the meat tough and flavorless and nothing really coming together as a main entree.  The veggie combo had a couple of decent dishes (out of five) but the portions were so small that they were forgettable. Wouldn't return here so the recommendation is pass.
author: Saminda W.

description: First time getting Ethiopian and was excited about their vegetarian options.  Would definitely go back next time I'm in the city, such a fun experience.  Also didn't wait long before food arrived at the table. :)
author: Caroline D.

description: Authentic Ethiopian cuisine with friendly service. I'm a regular here and have on many occasions ordered the kitfo wrap (medium rare) and the lamb tibs - both are extremely flavourful. Portions are quite large so be prepared to share or come hungry. Also highly recommend trying the Telba if you're looking for a beverage with your meal - it's made with only water, flaxseed and honey yet has a creamy almost milk smoothie texture. Extremely tasty, and very healthy as well. Love this place!
author: M K.

description:
Extremely pleasant workers. Delightfully sour injera. I got the chicken tibs ($13), which comes with your choice of veggie side. The tibs are a safe first timer choice, but are more or less the Ethiopian equivalent to fajitas. 

Overall, doesn't quite compare to the Ethiopian food in LA, but I'd try again with a more adventurous dish.
author: C W.

description:
Run don't walk. A welcome addition to the otherwise sterile yupster environment of Mission Bay. 

Yes it's more expensive than a 'traditional' Ethiopian joint, but that's SF. The person to bitch at is our worthless supervisors and your neighbors who fight development, not a restauranteur trying to make a go. 

Expect to pay $15/pp for a filling portion of meat, salads and all the Injera you can eat. I'll definitely be back. And I hope they get enough business to keep the location viable.
author: Jared S.

description:
I was so excited to know there would be an Ethiopian restaurant near me. They did not disappoint. My husband & I love this spot and it is our go to place for lunch/dinners. 

We usually get beef tibs, sambussa, beef berbere banatu and misir wot. Their service is also great - friendly and kind.
author: Sherin K.

description: I am so happy I took my friend here for dinner. The ambience was comfortable and ethic. The color scheme was attractive and the pieces on the wall were thoughtful. The service was excellent from the moment you walk in to the moment you walk out. We ordered at the front and took a number. Our food was brought to our table after fresh glasses of water were delivered. We ordered the lamb tib entree to share. This comes with injera and veggies, so for $18 it was a great deal. The injera was full of flavor and tasted like it was made fresh. It went perfectly with the lamb, hummus, and misir wot. I can't wait to come back
author: Elizabeth G.

description: True case of thievery. I had high expectations from Tadu. We paid for 3 main dishes and what we received was only comparable to 1. And when we tried to talk to the manager, we waited for 30 minutes before the waitress with the highest deplorable attitude tells us to give her our number since the manager is "busy" and she will call us. REALLY? Do you not know how to talk to PAYING customers. You omitted dishes from our order, then upon complaining you do nothing. We PAID for it and then we walked out since they didn't have an ounce of decency. It is my life's mission to let my entire neighborhood to know how terrible this business is. I have been here before once for lunch and they served proper portion then but I think the more you pay and tip the less food you get.
author: Prateek G.

description: I love this place. I haven't had anything short of delicious yet. The meat, veggies, everything. Great place for a casual meal.
author: Sabs B.

description:
It's Tadu! In Mission Bay!  Now you can have Tadu without braving the human feces and crazies endemic to their original Tenderloin location.

As with the original location, as soon as I tasted the special kitfo, it was revelatory. I have no words to describe this flavor except that I have never had anything like it and is the same here as the one in the Tenderloin. It is like pure flavor - and I strongly recommend you get it rare. As soon as it arrives I begin to eat it, and I become more and more compulsive about it until it is gone.

Very few things have this effect on me (dry rub BBQ ribs from The BBQ Shop in East Memphis is one of the others), but it is like a drug in its effect.

Suffice it to say: try Tadu. They only need a few more addicts like me to keep them in business indefinitely.
author: Marco C.

description: The food is really good. Many vegetarian options. They derive quickly and everyone is very helpful and nice. They have Mexico coke. The place is nice and clean.
author: Jiayin L.

description: The atmosphere and food were both amazing. The staff are also very polite and hospitable. I took my mom there for Mother's Day and she really enjoyed herself. We went back 2 weeks later. We will definitely be back soon!
author: Deja C.

description: Great food and great service! :) I got the veggie combo plate and loved it. Everyone on staff was very friendly and helpful.
author: Steph W.

description: I like the cuisine. This place is a great addition to the neighborhood. The place is very clean. Staff is well trained, super friendly & attentive. Food is very good specially the non vegetarian items on menu. There is good variety of vegetarian options. Our group of 6 ordered, two orders of sambusas, veg platter, non veg platter, lamb tibs & couple of vegetarian entrees. Everyone was happy with the food & portions. Injera is definitely a good variation for bread options. Will definitely come back for more.
author: Vipul Z.

description: I picked up food for a company team lunch We're a hard group to appease! Everything we ordered - gone! Delicious and tasty! Will definitely return!
author: Carol J.

description: The staff is really friendly and informative. The food was very good and the place was clean. It makes sense, they just opened. The server mentioned that they had another location on Ellis St. They seem to have it together, there are a ton of foot traffic and lots of people to dropping by and get food. Hopefully this could be a fun neighborhood spot, like most people say, it is about time good food comes to Mission Bay. This is like one and a half blocks from the Spark Social venue, good food, coffee and desserts.
author: Raymond L.

description: The food is amazing but the customer service is really what makes this place. They really go above and beyond to make sure you are happy as a patron.
author: Danielle L.

description: Yummy yummy! So glad they opened up this Mission Bay location since I live in nearby Bayview. The food is delicious and the service is exceptionally warm and friendly.
author: Missed F.

description: Beef mushroom tibs was pretty damn good. Great portion of sautéed steak cubes with mushrooms and onions. One of the sides, Alicha Tikil Gomen.. . They don't scam you on portions. This will probably my go to now if they change portion size. Did I mention Great service too!
author: Henry W.

description:
Great food. Get the lamb ribs and have them make it spicy. Heaven.

I have now come here four times in the last week and a half. I am addicted to the food from Tadu.
author: Anand A.

description: Very tasty food. The owner is VERY welcoming! He is always happy to lend a helping hand when you need something. I think he will go very far in his business. LONG LIVE TADU Restaurant
author: MIRELA P.

description: This place is wonderful. The food is great, the staff are attentive and friendly. It's a great option for vegetarians in the neighborhood and it's delicious. I want to try the breakfast sometime.
author: Celeste H.

description: Great new place and amazing flavors! Extremely good choice for a vegetarian.
author: Lakshmi R.

description: Great service! The veggie platter is fantastic (this coming from a born carnivore, you do not even miss meat). The lamb gomen (lamb and collard greens) is also very tasty.
author: Brett S.

description: Fantastic to have this foodie mecca in the neighborhood which is otherwise a bit of a bland medical complex. The room is spacious and clean, easy for groups or just eating on your own. The food if spicy and flavorful without being overwhelming. And great service.
author: Antonia T.

description: I am a huge fan of Ethiopian cuisine. I tried Tadu at 4th street for the first time and the experience was mind-blowing. The person at the counter was very kind and generous, his hospitality stands out of all things. I tried their meat combo and it was by far the best I have tasted in San Francisco.
author: Raghavan L.

description: Very tasty, original place. Quick and nice service. Dishes that you've probably never heard of.
author: Dominik S.

description:
The original Tadu in the Tenderloin is amazing. Easily one of my favorite Ethiopian restaurants.

However, this place is an utter disappointment. The combo I ordered was a LOT smaller than the Tenderloin version, more expensive, less tasty, and contained some weird beet thing instead of the usual types of vegetables.

Also, the place was freezing and the service horrible.

Go to the Tenderloin one instead, or to Moya.
author: Mal L.

description: It's too dark in here. It never looks open even when it is, and once inside it's hard to see your food because it's so dim. Please turn up the lights!
author: Clara S.

description: By far the greatest Ethiopian restaurant in the bay area! The food is amazing and they make you feel at home wherever you come. Try the tibs!
author: Abenezer M.

description: The vegetarian platter is awesome and it's vegan.  This is big because if you're in mission bay and are searching for vegan, you get suggestions to walk around a mile to eat at a shopping mall love hut or a mile and a half to reach a street cornrr flying falafel.  I am not prepared for a General Mao style Long March every time I want to eat and am very happy this place opened up.  The combo was fresh, healthy, tasty, and only slightly expensive.
author: Shai T.

description: Great food and service, but very overpriced. I ordered a dish (lamb tibbs) and a beer, which came out to $25 before tip.
author: Allen L.

description:
If you've never tried Ethiopian food you are missing out!  And tadu is great new place for it. Delicious meat and extremely flavorful veggie dishes.
Very tasty spot, nice casual atmosphere, great addition to the neighborhood
author: Peder L.

description: Delicious food. Great service. We tried the combo veggie and meat platters and enjoyed everything immensely! Favorites were the cabbage, the ground beef and the chickpeas but everything was tasty.
author: Katie B.

description: Atmosphere was awesome but food was a bit salty relative to other Ethiopian restaurants in San Francisco (like the one in the mission that is fantastic). I will go back, but it won't replace my pilgrimage to the mission.
author: Gina B.

description: Great Ethiopian food! Highly recommend the vegetarian combo - a good mix of all the veggie dishes. The food is really flavorful. Tadu also has a great atmosphere as well with awesome music and friendly and fast service. Will be coming here again!
author: Seema B.

description: Dreams do come true!!! The first location is amazing and so is this one. Amazing food, lovely owners, and great service!!! Get the lamb tins, veggie combo, and the special kitfo rare.
author: LAIKA K.

description: This was exactly what was needed in this neighborhood. The food was very good and the staff was very attentive even though it is an order at the counter and seat yourself model. We had the meat platter and the veggie platter shared between two of us. The food was so tasty and was equal or better to my favorite place in Boston. Don't be afraid to ask for help when ordering!
author: L S.

description:
Amazing food. Need more good Ethiopian restaurants in sf.

Great vegetarian platter and service.
author: Mahak B.

description: This place is a hidden gem in SF. The staff is super friendly, the food is amazing. I recommend everything
author: Kieran O.

description: Went here for a friends bday who had never tried Ethiopian before... really disappointed! First of all the veggie samples came smushed in a small plate... I'm not sure why, so right away the food was not appetizing. Further the flavors were satisfactory at best. Service was not so great either. The server didn't really know much about the menu or the artifacts kept there.
author: Nupur J.

description:
This place is great. Delicious food, nice-sized portions, friendly staff. I'm so excited to have a good Ethiopian place in my neighborhood. I will definitely be back!

Tip: the vegetarian combo is amazing!
author: Laura S.

description: How lucky we are to have an amazing ethnic restaurant like this in our neighborhood. The food is unbelievably flavorful, plus it's affordable and the staff is extraordinarily friendly.  They even have beer and wine to help you wash it down. But the flavors, oh the flavors... try as many dishes as you can and come back for more!
author: David H.

description: This place is great, I'm totally impressed. It just opened and is always empty, so I was skeptical. I got the mushroom plate with chickpeas and a drink for $14 and was pleasantly surprised by how good it was. Service was very attentive (which never happens somewhere that you order at the register). Restaurant is clean, well designed and plays good music. This is definitely gonna be a popular spot when people find out how good it is.
author: Amber P.

description: Delicious delicious delicious!! I never get bored of eating their  scrumptious veggie combo plate ever !! Just go for it !!!
author: Raja K.

description: I like the chicken tibs with kik alicha wot. The lamb tibs plate is also good. The service is good. They checked out several time for water and spice. It's my first time here and will definitely come back again.
author: Angela L.

description: First time eating Ethiopian food. Very flavorful and filling. Loved the honey wine too. People are very nice & clean space.
author: Melissa N.

description: This place is....DELICIOUS. First time trying Ethiopian food and it was a great experience. Staff is super friendly and food was full of flavor. Will definitely be back.
author: Food D.

description: Solid Ethiopian food and a fresh addition to Mission Bay. It's a bit pricey for an Ethiopian restaurant (especially for counter service), but to be expected for the area and rent. Meals can be served in the traditional family style or individually. We got a veggie combo and a meat combo. Portion size was ample. Injera was very good (light, spongy, not overly sour), and they have a teff-only/gluten-free option for +$3. The wots in the veggie combo were all yummy and standard. I've had tastier, fresher-tasting gomens though. Wish they had a more traditional salad (with the tomato and dressed lettuce) in the combos instead of just a few pieces of lettuce tucked between dishes. I liked the minchet abish wot (ground beef with berbere); tasted like the Eritrean zigni dish my aunt always makes. Spiced tea was a little different than I'm used to but nice with the meal -- although they did bring it out way after everything else was served. Service was fine, and seating was plentiful (although filled up by the time we left). Overall, a nice new option in the neighborhood.
author: Michelle F.

description: Other branch used to be my favorite Ethiopian place. Now everything has been downsized - a small piece of injera (which is not sour enough, making me wonder whether it's made with teff or not). The toppings have also dropped in quantity and tastiness.
author: Norcloud S.

description: What a delicious discovery! We went here with a party of 10 to celebrate my wife's birthday. She was craving Ethiopian food, and we wanted to try somewhere new. The service was wonderful--everyone was warm, friendly and inviting. They made us feel like we had been invited into their home. They helped us choose what to order for such a large party, and everything was incredibly flavorful (and reasonably priced). All of us, including four teens, left very happy and can't wait to return!
author: Marc E.

description: My first time trying Ethiopian cuisine and I'm hooked! The food was delicious and the service couldn't have been better. Highly recommend the sambussa as an appetizer and beef mushroom tibs as a main!
author: Laura C.

description: Great food. Quick service, good for lunch.  Wasn't busy but deserves to be. 2 dishes (1 meat 1 veg) was more than enough for 3 people. I will definitely go back next time I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Matt S.

description: Delicious food, though a little pricy for counter service lunch. However once you're seated the service is very good.  They checked with us several times and water was kept filled. The chicken tibs was flavorful and came with salad and a side,  plus a basket of injera bread. My only minor complaint is the injera is a little cold but still good and pleasantly sour and yeasty.
author: C C.

description: The best Ethiopian I've had outside of Ethiopia.  Everything is terrific. Great, fun atmosphere inside and easy to take out too. Great flavors and spices. The staff couldn't be more friendly and welcoming. Try the Ethiopian beer too.
author: Adam H.

description: This is my favorite Ethiopian restaurant in the city. Authentic Ethiopian food, food comes pretty fast and great location. It's a family owned restaurant which make it even better. Will definitely be back.
author: Soly A.

description: We love this place. We used to frequent Tadu often at tenderloin. Now it's awesome that this place is close to us.
author: Aparna N.

description: Yum! 2 people shared the vegetarian combo plate and an appetizer. They explained the menu to us when we said we were new to the cuisine. They were stingy with the injera, but we got more when we asked (without extra charge0. Food seems a bit overpriced, but that's the neighborhood for you...
author: F M.
